hierarchy.file_name: Design--Add standardized “Attribution Evidence” fields to Issue objects.docx

sections.text:
We should add a standardized “Attribution Evidence” section to the Issue object to capture the minimum structured inputs needed for impact attribution and to make later reporting/audits consistent. The section will include fields such as: impacted account(s) (IDs + names), revenue at risk / expected impact amount (currency + range/confidence), impact hypothesis (short freeform narrative with optional category tags), and linked downstream work (e.g., opportunity IDs, support ticket IDs, customer escalation IDs, project/task IDs). This section is explicitly not a computed attribution result; it is the source-of-truth evidence captured at the time the Issue is created/triaged.

On the data model, we’ll extend the Issue schema with a single nested object (e.g., `attributionEvidence`) containing typed subfields and metadata. Each field should support “unknown/not provided” states and store normalization details (system type, external ID, display label) for linked entities. We will also add audit metadata: `createdBy`, `createdAt`, and a change history that records each update as an immutable entry (old/new value, actor, timestamp, and optional reason). This ensures attribution inputs remain reviewable over time even as account ownership, pipeline amounts, or hypotheses evolve.

For capture consistency, the Issue creation/edit UI will include a compact panel with required/optional indicators and validation (e.g., numeric format, currency, entity ID format). We’ll support lightweight prefill from context when available: if an Issue is created from a support/CRM/pipeline integration, we populate impacted accounts and linked work IDs automatically and mark the source. For existing Issues, the section will default to empty and be editable by authorized roles; we should provide a simple “request evidence” workflow (e.g., a status check or warning) rather than blocking Issue creation.

Success criteria: the fields are present on all Issues, can be filled quickly during triage, and can be queried/exported for reporting using consistent types. We’ll measure adoption (% Issues with at least one impacted account and one linked downstream ID), completeness over time, and audit integrity (every change is attributable to an actor and timestamp). Rollout should include a backfill plan for Issues created via integrations (best-effort prefill) and a migration that does not disrupt existing Issue APIs/clients by making the new object optional and versioned.
